Clinton Defers Decision On National Missile Shield President Clinton said he did not believe the technology was ready for an effective national defense system, and he left the decision on moving ahead with the politically charged and diplomatically sensitive project to his successor.
The presidential nominees Al Gore and George W. Bush both welcomed President Clinton's announcement, but from different perspectives.
European leaders applauded the announcement, and Russian officials expressed satisfaction that their diplomatic campaign to galvanize opposition against the program had apparently played a role.

Concorde Crash Investigation A French team investigating the crash of an Air France Concorde in July issued a preliminary report Thursday that included exchanges between the control tower and the crew. It was also disclosed that a fire drill caused a runway inspection to be skipped the day of the crash.
Taiwan Leader on Unification President Chen Shui-bian, speaking in an interview, took a hard line toward China's government on the issue of when or even whether Taiwan and China would be unified.

Rebuff to Latin America Plan The presidents of South America's 12 countries, in a statement issued at a summit meeting in Brasilia, rebuffed President Clinton's recent appeal that they endorse an American-backed military and police offensive against drug trafficking and guerrilla groups in Colombia.

Mexican Generals Arrested Two generals long suspected of corruption have been arrested and imprisoned by the military on charges of collaborating with the Juarez drug cartel, prosecutors in Mexico City said. Their arrests on the eve of President Ernesto Zedillo's final State of the Union address were an additional blow to the reputation of the Mexican armed forces in their role as a narcotics enforcer.

Myanmar Standoff Ends Police officers forced opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi to return to the capital on Friday, ending her nine-day standoff against Myanmar's military government, a top opposition official said.

Bush Defends Attack Ad As Response to Gore Ads Gov. George W. Bush, interviewed aboard his campaign plane, defended a new ad that challenged the credibility and character of Vice President Al Gore, saying it was a way to counter Gore ads against him. He also signaled that his frequent pledge to ''change the tone'' of politics would not prevent him from raising questions about Mr. Gore's truthfulness and leadership abilities.
At a campaign appearance before 2,000 people in Louisiana, Mr. Bush assailed Mr. Gore's credibility.
Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, said that if elected, he would forfeit $3.5 million in stock options for Halliburton, the energy services company he left to run for office.

Debate commission officials rejected Bush campaign efforts seeking revisions to the locations and schedules of three debates in October. Officials said the arrangements were too far along. Mr. Bush said aides were studying options.

Scientist's Release Blocked Two federal appeals court judges halted the imminent release of Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets. The delay in Dr. Lee's release on bail resulted from a last-minute move by prosecutors that provoked accusations of deception from defense lawyers.

Prosecutors May Face Charges Ray Jahn and his wife, LeRoy Jahn, two federal prosecutors in Texas who helped send several Branch Davidians to prison, may soon be prosecuted on charges that they withheld information from a Congressional investigation of the Waco siege, their lawyers said.

Big Trouble in a Small Town Federal officials have filed criminal charges against 11 residents of Mattoon, Ill., and 8 other people in what they say was a bogus financial investment scheme that hoodwinked more than 10,000 people around the world out of $12.5 million.

English-Only Bias Settlement Watlow Electric Manufacturing will pay $192,500 to settle a civil rights case brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on behalf of eight Hispanic workers who were required to speak only English while working on the company's Batavia, Ill., assembly line.

U.N. Meeting Prompting Forecasts of Gridlock The Millennium Summit at the United Nations next week, billed as the biggest gathering of heads of state and government ''in human history,'' is expected to spawn huge traffic snarls, numerous demonstrations and heavy security measures.
The Long, Cool Summer Taken together, June, July and August were the 19th chilliest in the 124 years that records have been kept for New York City, with an average temperature of only 71 degrees.
Pakistani Band Members Desert Seven or eight members of a Pakistani Army pipe and drum band that came to New York for the Pakistani Independence Day Parade have apparently gone AWOL.
Apology for Cancer Ad People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals apologized to Mayor Giuliani for using his face on billboard advertisements linking milk consumption to prostate cancer.

Mrs. Clinton Aids Jailed Spy Hillary Rodham Clinton quietly intervened last week to stop Jonathan Pollard, the American convicted of spying for Israel, from being transferred to a more dangerous unit of the federal prison where he is serving a life sentence.

Nile Virus Case in New Jersey New Jersey reported its first human infection with the West Nile virus, in a 43-year-old Jersey City man, while New York reported its seventh, in a 61-year-old Staten Island man.

Williams Weathers Challenge Venus Williams defeated Meghann Shaughnessy, 7-6 (3), 6-1. Monica Seles and Jennifer Capriati, who played an epic Open semifinal in 1991, won their matches and will next face each other.
New Deal for Umpires The new umpires' union negotiated a five-year labor agreement, which must be ratified by the umpires and the club owners.

New Warning on Tire Safety Federal regulators warned of safety problems in many Firestone tires sold as replacements for factory-issued tires on sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, after Bridgestone/Firestone rebuffed a request to broaden its current tire recall.

Further Sign of a Slowdown Private employers created only 17,000 new jobs in August, and the unemployment rate rose to 4.1 percent from 4 percent. The data added to the belief that the Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates again this year.
The Dow gained 23.68 points, to 11,238.78; the S.& P. 500 rose 3.09 points, to 1,520.77; and the Nasdaq advanced 27.98 points, to 4,234.33.

Microsoft Assessed $1 Million A federal judge who questioned the truthfulness of statements made by William H. Gates has awarded $1 million in punitive damages to Bristol Technologies, which brought an antitrust suit against Microsoft.

Wartime Theft Case Settled The Quedlinburg art theft case, involving priceless religious artworks stolen by a G.I. in Germany at the end of World War II, has been quietly resolved. His heirs agreed to pay $135,000 in federal and Texas state taxes, penalties and interest.
Editorials: Mr. Cheney on defense; equal pay on the tennis court; Dudley Clendinen on caring for the elderly ill.
